lawSummary: Australian lease law is governed by state and territory legislation, with common law principles. Key acts include Residential Tenancies Acts in each state, which provide statutory protections for tenants and landlords. The law emphasizes fairness, habitability, and procedural protections.

requiredClauses.title: Termination and Notice
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Follow state-specific notice requirements (typically 14-90 days). Must specify valid grounds for termination. Cannot include retaliatory eviction clauses.

requiredClauses.title: Bond and Security
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Bond must be lodged with state authority. Follow state limits (typically 4 weeks rent). Specify return process and dispute resolution.

requiredClauses.title: Rent and Payment
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Rent increases must be reasonable and follow state guidelines. Specify payment methods and due dates. Include rent control provisions if applicable.

requiredClauses.title: Repairs and Maintenance
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Landlord responsible for major repairs. Include urgent repair process. Clearly define tenant's limited maintenance responsibilities.

requiredClauses.title: Privacy and Entry
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Specify notice requirements (typically 7-14 days). Limit entry to reasonable purposes. Respect tenant privacy rights.

requiredClauses.title: Sub-letting
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Cannot unreasonably withhold consent. Include reasonable approval process. Cannot charge excessive fees for consent.

requiredClauses.title: Utilities and Services
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Clearly specify utility responsibilities. Cannot charge excessive fees. Include service standards and complaint procedures.

requiredClauses.title: Dispute Resolution
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Include access to state tribunal system. Specify dispute resolution process. Cannot waive tribunal rights.
